title: With Resilience, NASA & SpaceX to begin operational Commercial Crew flights
summary: Weather and technology permitting, a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket is scheduled to lift off from the Kennedy Space Center, Florida, at 19:27 EST on 15 November (00:27 UTC on 16 November) lofting four space travelers into orbit ahead of a planned six month stay aboard the International Space Station.

title: Starship SN8 hoping for speedy return to testing as additional vehicles line up
summary: Following Starship SN8’s eventful Static Fire test, it was feared the test flight would likely suffer from a lengthy delay. However, thanks in part to a burst disk that avoided a damaging “pop” scenario, SN8 may yet still fly to 50,000 feet this month, albeit with a realigned trio of Raptor engines.

title: Rep. Doug Lamborn: U.S. needs plan to develop workforce for growing space sector
summary: Lamborn held a “Space Force Workforce Development Roundtable” event Nov. 12 at the U.S. Air Force Academy.

title: ULA declares success on Atlas 5 launch with new solid rocket boosters
summary: A top secret cargo for the U.S. government’s spy satellite agency soared into orbit from Cape Canaveral at the tip of a United Launch Alliance Atlas 5 rocket Friday night, successfully debuting a new solid-fueled booster design that ULA says are cheaper and easier to handle than previous strap-on motors.

title: Examining Crew-1 launch weather criteria and abort modes
summary: With each new crew launch from the U.S. comes the inevitable questions: Why all the weather rules?  What are the vehicle’s abort modes and how will it perform a launch abort and aim itself to a predetermined location in the Atlantic Ocean stretching from the Kennedy Space Center across to the western Irish coast?

title: First Rocket Lab U.S. launch delayed to 2021
summary: The first launch of Rocket Lab’s Electron rocket from a site in the United States won’t take place until 2021 because of problems with the flight termination system NASA requires the rocket to use.

title: Offshore conditions bump crew launch to Sunday
summary: Originally expected to take off Saturday, the launch of SpaceX’s first operational Crew Dragon mission was delayed to Sunday because of expected high winds at the Kennedy Space Center and weather off-shore where the Falcon 9 rocket’s first stage will attempt to land on a SpaceX droneship. The company plans to re-use the booster for the next Crew Dragon flight.

title: Atlas V successfully launches NROL-101
summary: United Launch Alliance’s Atlas V rocket carried a National Reconnaissance Office satellite to orbit Friday in a launch that marked a major milestone for the next-generation Vulcan rocket as Atlas V debuted the new GEM-63 solid rocket boosters from Northrop Grumman — the start of a switch away from the Aerojet Rocketdyne boosters.

title: ESA signs a trio of Copernicus contracts worth 1.3 billion euros
summary: The European Space Agency (ESA) signed contracts for three pairs of satellites for the agency's Earth-observing Copernicus program on Nov. 13 with a total award value of more than 1.3 billion euros ($1.54 billion).

title: Virgin Galactic executive to lead Australian Space Agency
summary: A longtime Virgin Galactic executive will return to Australia to take over the country’s young space agency, the Australian government announced Nov. 13.

title: Marine Corps stands up space unit at Offutt Air Force Base
summary: The Marine Corps activated a new unit called Marine Corps Forces Space Command as a subordinate organization to U.S. Space Command.

title: Weather delays Crew-1 launch
summary: NASA has postponed the launch of its first operational commercial crew mission by a day, citing weather conditions that delayed the arrival of the droneship used for the recovery of the Falcon 9 first stage.

title: ULA Atlas 5 launches National Reconnaissance Office satellite
summary: A National Reconnaissance Office satellite flew to orbit Nov. 13 aboard a United Launch Alliance Atlas 5 rocket.

title: Atlas 5 rocket back on the launch pad for national security mission
summary: A United Launch Alliance Atlas 5 rocket made its third trip to a Cape Canaveral launch pad Thursday, rolling into position for liftoff Friday afternoon with a classified payload for the U.S. government’s spy satellite agency.

title: Astronauts rehearse for launch day as mission managers watch weather
summary: The four astronauts preparing to ride SpaceX’s Crew Dragon “Resilience” into orbit climbed aboard their spaceship Thursday at the Kennedy Space Center in a practice run for a launch to the International Space Station planned Saturday night, while mission managers monitored weather and sea conditions in recovery areas across the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Long March 3B lofts second Tiantong-1 spacecraft
summary: China launched the second Tiantong-1 mobile communications satellite on Thursday. The launch took place at 15:59 UTC Long March-3B/G2 (Chang Zheng-3B/G2) from the LC2 Launch Complex at the Xichang Satellite Launch Center.

title: SpaceX conducts static fire test on Falcon 9 for Crew-1 mission
summary: SpaceX has conducted a Static Fire test on the Falcon 9 rocket tasked with the first operational Crew Dragon mission, Crew-1.  The flight will be SpaceX’s second crewed flight and their first rotation mission with four astronauts onboard.

title: Changing NASA requirements caused cost and schedule problems for Gateway
summary: The initial elements of NASA’s lunar Gateway are facing cost overruns and delays primarily because NASA has changed the requirements of the program since awarding contracts last year.

title: Spaceflight announces Sherpa tug with electric propulsion
summary: Rideshare launch service provider Spaceflight Inc. announced a new version of its Sherpa tug Nov. 12 equipped with electric propulsion that can send smallsats to high orbits or cislunar space.

title: Independent panel recommends delaying Mars Sample Return missions
summary: An independent review panel created by NASA to examine its plans to return samples from Mars endorsed the overall campaign, but recommended that the agency delay two upcoming missions to provide a more realistic development schedule.

title: Senate report criticizes Space Force plan to acquire secure, nuclear-survivable satcom
summary: The Senate Appropriations Committee questioned why it will take the U.S. Space Force 12 years to acquire new jam-resistant communications satellites.

title: Falcon 9 rocket fires up in crucial test before weekend crew launch
summary: SpaceX test-fired a Falcon 9 rocket Wednesday afternoon at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida, clearing a major hurdle before it launches Saturday night — weather permitting — with a four-person crew heading for the International Space Station.

title: Jim Bridenstine is leaving NASA. How should we assess his 30-month tenure?
summary: “I think he’s exceeded anyone’s expectations in the position.”

title: SpaceX, NASA, JAXA clear Crew-1 for launch; static fire delayed to Wednesday
summary: For the first time since 1982, NASA has certified a spaceship to operationally carry humans into low Earth orbit.

title: Senate bill offers NASA only a fraction of requested lunar lander funding
summary: A Senate appropriations bill would provide NASA with only a small fraction of the funding it requested for lunar lander development, putting any chance of returning humans to the moon by 2024 in jeopardy.

title: “Revolutionary change” expected from new Indian space policy
summary: A draft policy on opening up India’s space sector will bring transformational change, the chairman of the commercial arm of the Indian space agency said Nov. 10.

title: NASA certifies SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft ahead of Crew-1 launch
summary: NASA formally certified SpaceX’s Crew Dragon spacecraft for transporting astronauts to and from the International Space Station, clearing the way for a Nov. 14 launch.

title: Kleos Space raises funds for additional RF mapping clusters
summary: Luxembourg-based Kleos Space raised $13.8 million following the Nov. 7 launch of its first cluster of radio frequency mapping satellites.

title: Telesat remains optimistic about prospects for LEO constellation
summary: As SpaceX prepares to extend its Starlink beta test program to Canada, Telesat remains optimistic its broadband low Earth orbit constellation will find enough business to be successful.

title: Ex-Im reviewing nearly $2 billion in applications for space industry projects
summary: The Export-Import Bank of the United States is evaluating nearly $2 billion in applications to finance space industry sales as it seeks to return to a field that has changed significantly over the last few years.

title: NASA formally certifies SpaceX’s Crew Dragon for “operational” astronaut flights
summary: NASA officials gave approval Tuesday for SpaceX to begin regular crew rotation flights to the International Space Station with the launch of four astronauts set for Saturday from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, signaling a transition from development to operations for the human-rated Dragon spacecraft.

title: Independent Review Indicates NASA Prepared for Mars Sample Return Campaign
summary: NASA released an independent review report Tuesday indicating the agency is now ready to undertake its Mars Sample Return (MSR) campaign to bring pristine samples from Mars to Earth for scientific study.

title: NASA Science to Host Community Town Hall Meeting
summary: NASA’s Science Mission Directorate will hold a community town hall meeting with Associate Administrator for Science Thomas Zurbuchen and his leadership team at 3 p.m. EST Tuesday, Nov. 17, to discuss updates to NASA’s science programs, share the current status of activities, and roll out the agency’s 2021 NASA Science Planning Guide.

title: Relativity’s 3D-printed engine has completed a mission duty cycle test-firing
summary: "Despite coronavirus, we actually hit that target on track."

title: Large launch companies cast doubt on viability of small launch vehicle market
summary: Executives of major launch companies said they doubted there was sufficient demand for more than a few small launch vehicle developers, citing their own efforts to provide rideshare launch services for smallsats.

title: Japanese lunar lander company ispace opens U.S. office
summary: A Japanese company developing commercial lunar landers has opened an office in the United States in a bid to win more business from NASA’s Artemis program.

title: Euroconsult: Record number of smallsats launched in 2020
summary: Despite the coronavirus and the challenges that the pandemic has presented to the space industry, the number of satellites launched in 2020 will hit an all-time record.

title: APT Satellite orders new small HTS satellite from China’s CGWIC
summary: Fleet operator APT Satellite has contracted China Great Wall Industry Corp. to build its Apstar-6E satellite based on a new, small high-throughput platform.

title: U.S. Air Force taps Brig. Gen. Purdy to command 45th Space Wing
summary: Brig. Gen. Stephen Purdy has been named commander of the U.S. Space Force’s 45th Space Wing and and director of the Eastern Range at Patrick Air Force Base, Florida.

title: Space insurers hoping to break even after recent losses
summary: After two consecutive years of losses, the space insurance industry is hoping to break even this year while seeking continued increases in premiums.

title: Raytheon to acquire small satellite manufacturer Blue Canyon Technologies
summary: Raytheon announced Nov. 10 it intends to acquire Blue Canyon Technologies, a manufacturer of small satellites and spacecraft components.

title: Governments continue to dominate radar satellite data market
summary: Radar satellite operators continue to see the long-term promise of commercial markets and near-term demand from government customers, according to panelists speaking Nov. 10 at the virtual World Satellite Business Week conference.

title: Virgin Orbit CEO Hart: Smallsat launchers need governments as anchor customers
summary: Small satellite launch providers need governments to invest in a diversity of companies and to avoid creating monopolies, Virgin Orbit CEO Dan Hart said.

title: Senate defense appropriators take issue with agencies that buy launch services directly from providers
summary: Senate defense appropriators criticized the practice by some agencies of procuring launch services directly from commercial providers.

title: Firefly closes in on debut flight with rocket delivery to Vandenberg launch site
summary: Across the world, several startup launch providers such as Relativity Space, Astra, Virgin Orbit, and others are currently in fierce competition with one another to bring their in-development rockets into operation and obtain a share of the ever-growing small satellite launch market.

title: Meet Launcher, the rocket engine builder with just eight employees
summary: The company is making progress, completing a series of component tests in October.

title: NASA Invites Media to Briefing on Mars Sample Return Independent Review Board Report
summary: NASA will host a media teleconference at 11 a.m. EST Tuesday, Nov. 10, to discuss the findings and recommendations of the report by an agency-commissioned independent board about NASA’s plans with ESA (European Space Agency) for a Mars Sample Return mission.

title: New NASA Partnerships to Mature Commercial Space Technologies, Capabilities
summary: NASA has selected 17 U.S. companies for 20 partnerships to mature industry-developed space technologies for the Moon and beyond. The NASA and industry teams will design a 3D printing system for NASA’s Artemis lunar exploration program, test a simple method for removing dust from planetary solar arrays, mature a first-stage rocket recovery system fo

title: Photos: Crew Dragon and Falcon 9 ready for rollout to pad 39A
summary: SpaceX’s Crew Dragon “Resilience” spacecraft and Falcon 9 rocket — stretching 215 feet long — are ready for rollout to pad 39A at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in preparation for the launch of four astronauts Saturday night to the International Space Station.

title: Introducing China’s new commercial rocket, Ceres-1
summary: China’s latest commercial rocket, the Ceres-1 (Gushenxing-1) launch vehicle, has conducted its maiden launch this weekend, orbiting the Tianqi-11 satellite.

title: Crew-1 astronauts arrive for launch as Tropical Storm Eta looms
summary: Astronauts Victor Glover, Michael Hopkins, Shannon Walker, and Soichi Noguchi have arrived at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida for their upcoming launch to the International Space Station (ISS).

title: Crew Dragon astronauts arrive in Florida for launch preparations
summary: With eyes on Tropical Storm Eta approaching South Florida, the four astronauts set to launch next Saturday on a SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft arrived at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center on Sunday after flying from their home base in Houston.

title: New Chinese rocket successful in debut launch
summary: A new four-stage rocket operated by the Chinese launch company Galactic Energy succeeded on its inaugural flight Saturday, delivering a data relay microsatellite to an orbit 300 miles above Earth.

title: Photos: Crew-1 astronauts greeted at Kennedy Space Center
summary: Crew Dragon commander Mike Hopkins, pilot Victor Glover, and mission specialists Shannon Walker and Soichi Noguchi flew to the Kennedy Space Center on a NASA-chartered private jet Sunday, ready for a final week of training, refresher courses, and some time off before their launch to the International Space Station.

title: SLS continues post-hurricane cleanups and prepares for Core Stage Green Run valve repair
summary:
NASA and Boeing continued troubleshooting issues with the Space Launch System (SLS) Core Stage found during summer Green Run testing while cleanup from the mess created by Hurricane Zeta continued in the greater New Orleans area. The hurricane plowed through NASA facilities in the area on the evening of October 28, causing roof and siding damage at the Michoud Assembly Facility (MAF) in New Orleans East and knocking out power across a wide part of the metro region.

Boeing is the prime contractor for the SLS Core Stage and is conducting the Green Run test campaign at the Stennis Space Center in nearby Southern Mississippi; NASA believes they have identified the cause of an intermittent fault with a liquid hydrogen (LH2) prevalve and are preparing to perform repairs. Stennis was also hit by Zeta, but saw less intense conditions than MAF as the storm weakened racing inland and the space agency is still hoping to complete the final Green Run tests by the end of the year.

title: Indian PSLV deploys 10 satellites in first launch since start of pandemic
summary: A Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle lifted off Saturday with India’s EOS 1 radar imaging satellite and nine rideshare payloads for customers based in the United States, Luxembourg, and Lithuania. The successful mission was India’s first launch in nearly a year due to delays caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Weather and technical problems further delay SLS Green Run test
summary: A critical test of the core stage of the Space Launch System is facing another delay, this time because of a combination of weather and technical issues that may push back the test to the end of the year.

title: ISRO returns from COVID stand down with EOS-1 mission
summary: The Indian Space Research Organization, ISRO, conducted the 51st launch of their Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle, otherwise known as the PSLV, carrying the EOS-1 Earth observation satellite and nine small satellite rideshare payloads into orbit.

title: Northrop Grumman updates Transfer Element portion of National Team lunar lander
summary: In an interview with NASASpaceflight, Northrop Grumman’s Sally Richardson, Program Director, Human Landing System, provided key updates on the progress the company is making on its Transfer Element, part of a three-piece Human Landing System (HLS) lunar lander.

title: Long March 6 lofts ten Argentinian satellites
summary: China has launched the first dedicated mission to orbit ten satellites for the Aleph-1 Argentinian Earth observation satellites. Launch took place at 03:19 UTC on Friday, 6 November 2020.

title: Rocket Report: SLS has technical problems, Vector—yes, Vector—is back
summary: “We thought there was tremendous value.”

title: SpaceX launches GPS navigation satellite from Cape Canaveral
summary: SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket Thursday from Cape Canaveral with the U.S. Space Force’s newest third-generation Global Positioning System navigation satellite, helping clear the way for the launch of SpaceX’s first operational Crew Dragon astronaut mission later this month.

title: Atlas 5 takes shelter from Tropical Depression Eta
summary: With Tropical Depression Eta forecast to restrengthen into a tropical storm and move toward Florida, United Launch Alliance moved an Atlas 5 rocket off its launch pad at Cape Canaveral Friday and delayed liftoff with a U.S. government spy satellite to Wednesday.

title: Ten Satellogic Earth-imaging satellites successfully launched
summary: Ten small high-resolution observation satellites for Satellogic — an Argentine company in the midst of deploying a fleet of Earth-imaging spacecraft — successfully launched Friday on a Chinese Long March 6 rocket.

title: Crew Dragon “Resilience” meets Falcon 9 rocket at Florida spaceport
summary: Fully fueled for a flight to the International Space Station later this month, SpaceX transferred the Crew Dragon “Resilience” spaceship Thursday to a hangar near pad 39A at the Kennedy Space Center for attachment to its Falcon 9 launcher.

title: Chinese rocket firm Galactic Energy succeeds with first orbital launch, secures funding
summary: Chinese rocket firm Galactic Energy successfully sent a small satellite into orbit Saturday with the first launch of its Ceres-1 launch vehicle.

title: India back in action with launch of Earth observation satellite, nine rideshare small sats
summary: The Indian Space Research Organisation successfully carried out its first launch since the COVID-19 outbreak Saturday sending the EOS-1 Earth observation satellite and nine smaller payloads into orbit.

title: SpaceX launches Space Force mission, appears to settle engine issue [Updated]
summary: Weather currently is expected to be 60 percent favorable for a launch.

title: Rocket Lab is about to attempt a first-stage recovery
summary: “Parachutes are not trivial things to get right.”

title: After month-long stand down, SpaceX launches fourth GPS III launch
summary: SpaceX successfully launched its Falcon 9 mission with the fourth GPSII satellite at 18:24 EST (23:24 UTC) on Thursday, 5 November.

title: NASA Seeks New Partners to Help Put All Eyes on Artemis Moon Missions
summary: NASA is seeking new partners to help the agency tell the story of human exploration at the Moon with the Artemis program in ways that engage, excite, and inspire a worldwide audience.

title: Texas satellite company defends itself against NASA criticisms
summary: “We’re not a bunch of cowboys launching satellites.”

title: Spacety launches satellite to test ThrustMe iodine electric propulsion and constellation technologies
summary: French propulsion startup ThrustMe is preparing to conduct an in-orbit demonstration of an iodine electric propulsion system on a 12-unit Spacety cubesat launched Nov. 6 at 10:19 Eastern time on a Chinese Long March 6 rocket.

title: China sets targets for smart, recoverable and reusable launch vehicles
summary: China’s main space contractor is developing launch vehicles capable of learning and adapting as well as multiple technologies for recovering and reusing rockets.

title: EchoStar launch of Jupiter 3 broadband satellite slips to 2022
summary: EchoStar Corp. plans to launch the Jupiter 3 broadband satellite in the first quarter of 2022 but has not yet selected a launch provider, company officials said during a Nov. 5 earnings call.

title: Airbus, Raytheon protest Space Development Agency satellite contract awards
summary: Airbus and Raytheon have filed protests with the Government Accountability Office challenging Space Development Agency contracts awarded to L3Harris and SpaceX last month for eight missile-tracking satellites, putting the projects on hold until the dispute is resolved.

title: Satellogic launches 10 satellites to provide high-resolution imagery
summary: With the successful launch of 10 satellites, Earth observation company Satellogic says it can now move ahead of its rivals in providing high-resolution imagery.

title: Key senator raises doubts about 2024 human lunar return
summary: A key senator says she will continue to push for passage during a lame-duck session of a NASA authorization bill that supports the Artemis lunar exploration program, but not necessarily the agency’s goal of return humans to the moon by 2024.

title: Raytheon, L3Harris, BAE Systems get $552 million for GPS user equipment
summary: Raytheon, L3Harris and BAE collectively received $552.5 million in contracts to develop and produce integrated circuit cards for military GPS receivers.

title: Maxar eyes September 2021 launch for WorldView Legion satellites
summary: Maxar Technologies plans to launch its first two WorldView Legion satellites as early as September 2021 on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

title: It’s a NRO-go for an Atlas V launch on Wednesday night [Updated]
summary: Rocket will try out new boosters on this launch.

title: C-band bonanza bails out sluggish year for satellite orders
summary: With an eye toward the FCC’s 2023 deadline, Intelsat and SES went on a shopping spree. But the C-band bonanza isn’t likely to be repeated anytime soon.

title: Rocket Lab to attempt Electron stage recovery on next launch
summary: Rocket Lab will try to recover the first stage of its Electron rocket on its next launch as the company continues its efforts to reuse that stage.

title: New report outlines international approach to lunar exploration
summary: An updated version of a study developed by an international working group backs an approach to lunar exploration that largely follows NASA’s Artemis plans to return humans to the moon in 2024.

title: NGA adds Planet, BlackSky to imagery delivery system used by government agencies
summary: Planet and BlackSky imagery will be added to NGA's unclassified system that delivers geospatial data to government agencies.

title: SpaceX launches U.S. Space Force GPS 3 satellite
summary: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launched a U.S. Space Force GPS 3 satellite Nov. 5 at 6:24 p.m. Eastern.

title: Virgin Galactic prepares to transition to operations
summary: Virgin Galactic executives said Nov. 5 that the company is ready to begin a final series of test flights of its SpaceShipTwo suborbital vehicle as the company attempts to move into commercial operations in 2021.

title: Baldridge replaces Dankberg as Viasat CEO
summary: Mark Dankberg, Viasat founder, chairman and CEO moved into the newly created role of executive chairman Nov. 3 as Rick Baldridge, Viasat’s former chief operating officer, became Viasat’s new CEO while retaining his role as president.

title: CHEOPS Second Announcement of Opportunity (AO-2)
summary: Proposals are solicited in response to the second Announcement of Opportunity (AO-2) for observing time in the CHEOPS Guest Observers Programme. This AO covers the period 26 March 2021 to 25 March 2022. The deadline for proposals is 1 December 2020, 13:00 CET/12:00 GMT.

title: Rocket Lab to attempt booster recovery on next mission
summary: On its next mission set for liftoff later this month, Rocket Lab will try to recover the first stage of its Electron small satellite launcher after parachuting into the Pacific Ocean downrange from the company’s privately-run spaceport in New Zealand, officials announced Thursday.

title: NASA calls Voyager 2, and the spacecraft answers from interstellar space
summary: The spacecraft is so far south it can only talk to one Earth-bound antenna.

title: NASA TV Coverage Set for First Crew Rotation Flight on US Commercial Spacecraft
summary: NASA will provide coverage of the upcoming prelaunch and launch activities for the agency’s SpaceX Crew-1 mission with astronauts to the International Space Station.

title: Former astronaut Mark Kelly wins Senate race in Arizona
summary: Former NASA astronaut Mark Kelly won his race for the U.S. Senate in Arizona Nov. 3 while two members of Congress involved in space issues lost their bids for reelection.

title: ESA awards €1.5 million to three German launch startups
summary: The European Space Agency awarded German launch startups HyImpulse Technologies, Rocket Factory Augsburg, and Isar Aerospace a combined 1.5 million euros ($1.7 million) to support development of competing smallsat launchers.

title: ULA scrubs Atlas 5 launch as SpaceX readies repaired rocket for GPS mission
summary: United Launch Alliance called off the planned launch of an Atlas 5 rocket Wednesday at Cape Canaveral to resolve a problem with valves at the launch pad, while a SpaceX team a mile-and-a-half to the south readied a Falcon 9 rocket for liftoff Thursday evening with a GPS navigation satellite for the U.S. military.

title: Photos: Atlas 5 rolls to launch pad with new solid rocket boosters
summary: A United Launch Alliance Atlas 5 rocket with a new type of solid rocket booster emerged from its hangar Tuesday evening for the 1,800-foot rollout to pad 41 at Cape Canaveral, moving into position for liftoff Wednesday with a classified National Reconnaissance Office payload.

title: NASA objects to new mega-constellation, citing risk of “catastrophic collision”
summary: “This particular region of space tends to produce a large number of conjunctions.”

title: Europe’s “best answer” to competition from SpaceX slips again, will cost more
summary: The Ariane 6 was designed to be more cost effective to fly.

title: NASA Awards Contract for Engineering, Technical Support Services
summary: NASA has selected ASRC Federal Systems Solutions of Beltsville, Maryland, to perform engineering and technical support services for Research Facilities and Engineering Support Services (RF&ESS) for the Mission Support Directorate at the agency’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California
